title: Budget support to developing countries: REPORT The future of EU budget support to developing countries
background: The EU’s use of budget support to developing countries, established under the Lisbon Treaty (2009) and linked to UN Millennium Declaration goals, has faced scrutiny over governance standards, corruption risks, and aid effectiveness. The Parliament will discuss optimizing this instrument’s role in poverty reduction while addressing accountability challenges.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the conditional budget support framework emphasizing governance and anti-corruption measures, aligning perfectly with their commitment to transparent, accountable aid delivery.  
EPP approves the integration of civil society and parliamentary oversight in development strategies, ensuring local ownership and reinforcing democratic processes as prioritized in the issue.  
EPP endorses results-based incentives and predictable disbursements, recognizing their critical role in advancing poverty reduction and sustainable growth in line with EU development goals.  
EPP proposes enhancing real-time monitoring mechanisms within risk management frameworks to preempt irregularities, thereby strengthening safeguards for EU taxpayer funds without opposing the issue’s core principles.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of independent evaluation systems and tailored indicators, fully supporting the issue’s rejection of a one-size-fits-all approach to maximize context-specific aid effectiveness.

EFD supports the issue’s conditional approach to budget support, particularly its focus on governance accountability and anti-corruption safeguards as prerequisites for aid effectiveness.  
EFD advises strengthening pre-assessment mechanisms to rigorously evaluate recipient countries’ financial management systems before disbursing funds, ensuring alignment with their emphasis on responsible stewardship.  
EFD endorses the emphasis on civil society involvement in monitoring processes, urging explicit inclusion of local watchdog organizations to enhance transparency.  
EFD concurs with the rejection of a “one-size-fits-all” framework, advocating for deeper contextual analysis of domestic tax policies to avoid undermining fiscal autonomy.  
EFD highlights the need for accelerated implementation of risk management tools to address fraud concerns, proposing quarterly audits as a supplementary safeguard.

GREEN_EFA entirely approves the issue’s emphasis on civil society and parliamentary oversight in budget support, perfectly aligning with their commitment to participatory governance and accountability.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call for long-term engagement in sectors like education and health, recognizing this as essential to sustainable development as outlined in their 2023 climate-justice manifesto.  
GREEN_EFA entirely approves the rejection of a "one-size-fits-all" approach, emphasizing their principle of context-specific solutions that respect recipient countries’ ownership.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s multidimensional poverty reduction focus, which mirrors their advocacy for integrating gender, environmental, and social justice into all development frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA entirely approves the insistence on anti-corruption safeguards, reflecting their longstanding demand for transparency in EU aid to protect public funds and legitimacy.

ALDE completely accepts the issue’s transparency mandates, proposing monthly publicized online updates on aid outcomes to operationalize Article 12’s public register clause and empower citizen oversight.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with governance conditionality requirements, advocating intensified parliamentary scrutiny of fund flows to preempt arms trade risks while upholding anti-corruption frameworks in Section 4(b).  
ALDE unequivocally supports civil society inclusion in monitoring mechanisms, urging granular fraud audits to concretize Resolution Paragraph 9’s accountability provisions.  
ALDE champions the issue’s rejection of uniform approaches, emphasizing context-specific disbursement criteria to align with ALDE’s localization principles in MDG advancement.  
ALDE affirms the 0.7% GDP target as non-negotiable, demanding accelerated compliance timelines to realize poverty reduction imperatives under the Lisbon Treaty.

SD strongly approves the issue’s prioritization of poverty reduction through sectoral budget support, aligning perfectly with S&D’s commitment to advancing health and education access as foundational development pillars.  

SD approves the integration of gender perspectives into budget support conditionality, effectively advancing the issue’s multidimensional approach to addressing systemic inequalities.  

SD highlights the necessity of involving national parliaments and local authorities in budget support oversight, reinforcing the issue’s emphasis on ownership and participatory governance frameworks.  

SD proposes enhancing dynamic admissibility criteria to ensure poverty reduction indicators evolve with contextual needs, a minor refinement to strengthen the issue’s results-based methodology.  

SD applauds the focus on strengthening public financial management systems through budget support, which aligns with S&D’s longstanding advocacy for institutional capacity-building to combat corruption.

GUE_NGL supports the emphasis on poverty reduction as a primary objective but advises incorporating explicit critiques of structural adjustment programs imposed by international financial institutions to address systemic inequalities.  

GUE_NGL endorses conditional governance requirements while suggesting enhanced debt relief mechanisms be integrated into budget support frameworks to rectify historical injustices in North-South relations.  

GUE_NGL expresses concern over the issue’s insufficient attention to dismantling trade dependencies, urging policy coherence that prioritizes sovereign economic strategies over extractive partnerships.  

GUE_NGL advises strengthening civil society oversight provisions by mandating recipient-state parliamentary approval for all EU-funded governance indicators to ensure genuine local ownership.  

GUE_NGL acknowledges progress in anti-corruption safeguards but cautions that aid predictability must not circumvent domestic resource mobilization through binding commitments to progressive taxation reforms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of enhancing the effectiveness of budget support as a tool for delivering development aid, emphasizing poverty reduction as the EU’s primary objective under the Lisbon Treaty, with a multidimensional approach addressing economic, social, gender, environmental, and governance challenges. It stressed that budget support must be conditional on transparent governance, anti-corruption measures, and accountability mechanisms, including civil society and parliamentary involvement in designing, monitoring, and evaluating development strategies to ensure ownership by recipient countries. The resolution highlighted the need for results-based incentives, predictable disbursements, and adherence to human rights and governance standards, while cautioning that budget support should not undermine domestic resource mobilization, such as taxation, to reduce aid dependency. It called for EU-level independent evaluation systems, a public register for transparency in agreements and indicators, and policy coherence across EU trade, climate, agriculture, and security policies to align with development goals. The Parliament urged compliance with the 0.7% GDP target for development aid, criticized insufficient data in the Commission’s consultation process, and advocated for improved coordination among EU institutions and member states to avoid overlaps and strengthen impact. It also emphasized the role of sectoral budget support in advancing Millennium Development Goals, the need for risk management frameworks, and the importance of addressing fraud and corruption to safeguard aid legitimacy, while rejecting a "one-size-fits-all" approach in favor of tailored indicators and local context considerations.

title: Establishing a financing instrument for development cooperation: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a financing instrument for development cooperation
background: The EU's existing external financing instruments required reform to address evolving global challenges, enhance strategic partnerships, and ensure coherence in development cooperation. Geopolitical shifts, differentiated approaches to partner countries, and alignment with EU priorities necessitated updated mechanisms. The Parliament will discuss establishing a new financing framework for development cooperation and external action for 2014-2020.

stances.stance:
EPP totally sanctions the enhanced flexibility and crisis response capabilities of the stability instrument, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to coherent EU external action.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's prioritization of child mortality reduction through development cooperation, affirming its manifesto focus on tangible humanitarian outcomes.  
EPP totally sanctions the dedicated funding for election observation missions and civil society support, which advances EPP's democratic governance priorities as outlined in Article 209(1).  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's strategic focus on Latin American partnerships, recognizing this as critical to institutional cooperation under the Treaty framework.  
EPP totally sanctions the integration of cybersecurity provisions for cross-border threats, reflecting EPP's longstanding emphasis on security-development synergies in external instruments.

EFD conditionally promotes the financing instrument's framework but requests revisions to Article 294 provisions enabling parallel EU/national implementation structures, which contradict subsidiarity principles.  
EFD completely disapproves the issue's expansion of EU diplomatic networks, demanding amendment of Clause 7(b) to cap embassy expenditures at 50% of equivalent national mission costs.  
The proposal overlooks critical cost-control mechanisms, requiring insertion of salary alignment rules ensuring no EU official receives remuneration exceeding heads of government in member states.  
EFD rejects the budgetary assumptions underlying Annex II, citing incompatibility with their manifesto commitment to reduce EU operational spending by 30% before 2025.  
This instrument's lack of binding efficiency audits conflicts with EFD's core principle that all development funds must undergo quarterly national parliamentary scrutiny.

GREEN_EFA totally agrees the issue’s integration of democracy, rule of law, and human rights as central pillars of development cooperation, perfectly aligning with their foundational commitment to transformative governance reforms.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the inclusion of precise indicators and the "more for more" principle, which effectively advance accountability and incentivize democratic progress in partner countries.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s recognition of civil society’s indispensable role in policy design and evaluation, reflecting their longstanding advocacy for participatory development frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the necessity of future budgetary expansions to address funding gaps, framing this as a critical enhancement opportunity to maximize the instrument’s impact on poverty eradication.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on parliamentary oversight and institutional coherence, reinforcing their mandate to uphold transparency and Treaty obligations.

ALDE strongly sanctions the enhanced visibility and citizen-focused implementation of EU development aid, aligning with the issue's emphasis on making assistance tangible for beneficiaries in accession countries.  
ALDE proposes strengthening monitoring mechanisms to ensure funding flexibility directly benefits civil society and human rights defenders, enhancing the issue's accountability framework.  
ALDE applauds the partnership instrument’s role in advancing Europe 2020 Strategy goals globally, effectively matching ALDE’s priorities for market access and EU visibility.  
ALDE endorses the issue’s focus on policy coherence while recommending explicit emphasis on complementarity with national development programs to maximize collective impact.  
ALDE approves the prioritization of judiciary reforms (Chapters 23-24) as critical to democratic governance, reflecting ALDE’s longstanding commitment to rule-of-law conditionality.

SD completely supports the issue's emphasis on parliamentary oversight and transparency in development financing, perfectly aligning with S&D's commitment to democratic accountability in EU external action.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's integration of human rights conditionality, particularly welcoming the new protection mechanisms for defenders as articulated in the debate's focus on risk-taking humanitarian interventions.  
SD fully supports the reinforced gender equality provisions and poverty eradication targeting, mirroring the debate's insistence on directing aid to "the most needy" through social service benchmarks.  
SD endorses the issue's budgetary coherence mechanisms as effectively advancing S&D's vision of crisis-responsive development cooperation under constrained financial conditions.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's rejection of geopolitical confrontation strategies, upholding the debate's call for partnership-based approaches to neighborhood policy and Black Sea cooperation.

GUE_NGL partly accepts the issue’s framework but demands binding amendments to Articles 3-5 to replace non-binding "strategic dialogue" pledges with enforceable parliamentary oversight mechanisms.  
GUE_NGL completely disputes the subordination of development cooperation to EU security interests, urging deletion of clauses allowing EAD-led interventions prioritizing geostrategic objectives over social justice.  
GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s implicit endorsement of economic deregulation conditionality, proposing revised wording in Annex II to prohibit imposing privatization mandates on partner states.  
GUE_NGL highlights contradictions in territorial application, insisting the text explicitly exclude funding for projects in occupied Palestinian territories until occupation ends, per international law.  
GUE_NGL requests revisions to Annex I to mandate annual public audits of Stability Instrument expenditures, addressing transparency gaps that perpetuate militarized interventions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its adoption of a position at first reading on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0840), endorsing Parliament’s own statement and a joint statement with the Council and Commission to ensure alignment on implementation. It acknowledged annexed Commission statements while emphasizing the need for transparency, urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial amendments or replacements arise, thereby safeguarding parliamentary oversight. The resolution stressed forwarding the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing institutional cooperation and adherence to procedural obligations under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, particularly Articles 209(1) and 294. It highlighted commitments to development policy coherence, gender equality, and budgetary accountability, reflecting inputs from relevant parliamentary committees, though specific numerical targets or funding allocations were not detailed in the resolution text.

title: Motions for resolutions - Prospects for the Doha Development Agenda following the Seventh WTO Ministerial Conference: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the prospects for the Doha Development Agenda (DDA) following the Seventh WTO Ministerial Conference
background: The Doha Development Agenda, launched in 2001 to address trade imbalances and integrate developing countries, faced prolonged negotiations stalled since 2008 amid global economic crisis impacts on trade. The Seventh WTO Ministerial Conference (2009) reviewed progress without formal DDA negotiations. The Parliament will discuss the DDA's prospects and the EU's role in advancing multilateral trade governance.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the issue’s emphasis on concluding the Doha Round with an ambitious, balanced outcome, aligning with their commitment to equitable globalization and crisis resilience through WTO-led multilateralism.  
EPP fully accepts strict adherence to EU agricultural mandates, including robust geographical indications protection, as vital for safeguarding European interests while advancing fair global trade rules.  
EPP applauds the focus on integrating developing countries into the global trading system, particularly through duty-free, quota-free access for LDCs, mirroring their longstanding advocacy for development-centered trade policies.  
EPP proposes enhancing climate integration in WTO reforms by linking trade concessions to verifiable CO₂ reduction commitments, ensuring environmental sustainability complements market access goals.   
EPP strongly agrees institutional cooperation between the WTO and UN bodies like the ILO, emphasizing this synergy as critical to advancing decent labor standards alongside trade liberalization.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's insistence on concluding the Doha Round, firmly disputeing with their position that "the WTO needs to work on a reform" rather than perpetuating a "dead" negotiation framework.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the issue's endorsement of liberalization policies, which they argue are "partly responsible for the economic and financial crisis" and contradict their demand for prioritizing food sovereignty over market access.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as the "negative net effect for most developing countries," directly opposing GREEN_EFA's assessment that the Doha agenda "destabilises markets" instead of delivering equitable benefits.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's failure to abandon agricultural liberalization mandates, which they deem incompatible with their call to halt "industrialised states' rationalisation pressures" harming small-scale producers.  
This firmly disputes with GREEN_EFA's insistence on terminating "twenty year liberalisation policy" paradigms, demanding instead binding climate and labor rules rather than "wait[ing] until the crisis is over."

ALDE strongly upholds the urgent conclusion of the Doha Round as critical to global economic recovery, aligning with ALDE's leadership in advancing multilateral trade frameworks that integrate developing nations through equitable market access.  
ALDE approves the issue's emphasis on EU bridging roles between major economies and developing countries, effectively advancing ALDE's priority of fostering consensus-driven solutions in WTO negotiations.  
ALDE endorses strict abolition of agricultural export subsidies and enhanced Aid for Trade mechanisms, which align perfectly with ALDE's commitments to dismantling trade distortions affecting LDC competitiveness.  
ALDE proposes strengthening parliamentary oversight provisions by amending the interinstitutional agreement to mandate real-time negotiation updates, ensuring full transparency under Lisbon Treaty principles without delaying ratification processes.  
ALDE applauds the issue's rejection of bilateral agreement fragmentation, strongly upholding its call to maintain Doha's centrality in addressing climate and labor standards through institutional WTO reforms.

SD entirely conflicts the issue's market access priorities as contradicting S&D's demand for development-centered trade reform.  
SD rejects the services liberalization framework for failing to exempt public services from WTO rules as critical for social rights.  
The proposal conflicts with SD's agricultural sovereignty principles by inadequately protecting developing countries' special products and safeguard mechanisms.  
SD condemns the issue's approach to NAMA tariff cuts as disregarding developing nations' right to policy space for industrial development.  
The text overlooks SD's core demand to prioritize subsistence agriculture over export-oriented trade rules worsening food insecurity.

ECR strongly accepts the issue's emphasis on avoiding protectionism and integrating least developed countries into global trade, aligning perfectly with their commitment to market-driven economic growth and multilateral cooperation.  
ECR approves the balanced approach to concluding the Doha Round, particularly the call for EU leadership in mediating full participation of developing nations while maintaining special treatment provisions.  
ECR endorses the issue's recognition of bilateral and regional trade agreements as complementary tools, reinforcing their longstanding advocacy for pragmatic trade expansion beyond multilateral frameworks.  
ECR proposes enhancing transparency in implementing agricultural mandates to ensure CAP reforms do not inadvertently restrict market access opportunities for non-EU partners.  
ECR applauds the focus on WTO institutional reforms addressing climate change and food security, which aligns with their agenda of modernizing trade governance while preserving national regulatory autonomy.

GUE/NGL rejects the issue's endorsement of concluding the Doha Round as it perpetuates a failed neoliberal framework that exacerbates global inequality and environmental destruction.  
GUE/NGL opposes fundamentally the promotion of services liberalization, which undermines sovereign control over public goods like healthcare and education as highlighted in Ilda Figueiredo's critique.  
This proposal conflicts irreconcilably with GUE/NGL's demand for regulated trade systems prioritizing food sovereignty over corporate interests, as articulated in Jacky Hénin's condemnation of WTO-led crises.  
The issue's anti-protectionist stance directly contradicts GUE/NGL's call for socially just trade barriers to prevent wage suppression and ecological dumping.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue's omission of concrete measures against tax havens and financial speculation, which Figueiredo identified as root causes of systemic poverty.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its commitment to the WTO-led multilateral trading system as essential for equitable globalization and crisis resilience, emphasizing the Doha Development Agenda’s (DDA) role in integrating developing countries, particularly LDCs, through fair trade rules and special treatment. It urged concluding the Doha Round with a balanced, ambitious outcome to spur global economic recovery, stressing the need for developed and emerging economies to offer 100% duty-free, quota-free access for LDCs (mirroring the EU’s Everything but Arms initiative) and enhance Aid for Trade. The resolution called for strict adherence to EU agricultural mandates, including CAP reforms and geographical indications protection, while advocating substantial non-agricultural market access (NAMA) cuts with differential treatment for developing nations and services liberalization that respects public policy goals. It highlighted WTO institutional reforms to address climate change, food security, and labor standards, alongside strengthened cooperation with UN bodies like FAO and ILO. The Parliament demanded greater democratic scrutiny of EU trade policy under the Lisbon Treaty, including parliamentary involvement in negotiations and updates to interinstitutional agreements to ensure transparency. It also endorsed bilateral/regional trade agreements as complementary to multilateral frameworks and stressed the WTO’s role in curbing protectionism during economic crises.

title: Progress towards the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals: mid-term review in preparation of the UN high-level meeting in September 2010: REPORT on progress towards the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals: mid-term review in preparation of the UN high-level meeting in September 2010
background: In 2000, UN member states adopted the Millennium Development Goals targeting poverty reduction and sustainable development by 2015. By 2010, mid-term assessments highlighted uneven progress amid global economic instability and climate challenges. The Parliament will discuss progress toward achieving the Millennium Development Goals ahead of the 2010 UN high-level review.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly conflicts the issue's promotion of abortion access in paragraph 42, conflicting with their core principles of protecting human dignity and life from conception.  
EPP rejects the proposed Tobin tax in paragraph 8 as economically unworkable and inconsistent with effective development financing mechanisms.  
EPP opposes debt cancellation demands in paragraph 13, arguing this undermines partner countries' accountability for sustainable development processes.  
EPP disputes the call to eliminate agricultural export subsidies in paragraph 22, citing existential risks to European farmers during economic instability.  
EPP challenges the 0.7% GNI aid target framework as insufficiently focused on corruption prevention and private-sector growth strategies.

EFD rejects the issue's call for increased financial commitments as fundamentally incompatible with their stance against EU-driven austerity and economic overreach.  
EFD opposes the 0.7% GNI target for development aid, asserting it disregards the fiscal realities of indebted EU member states and their need for stringent spending cuts.  
The proposal's emphasis on EU policy coherence conflicts with EFD's demand to dismantle EU trade barriers and regulations that "strangl[e] businesses" across Europe.  
EFD condemns the issue's failure to address core structural issues like abolishing the euro and enabling national currencies, which they deem essential for economic recovery.  
This initiative overlooks EFD's paramount objective of British EU withdrawal, which they argue would liberate resources for direct bilateral trade with developing nations.

GREEN_EFA completely upholds the issue’s urgent reaffirmation of MDG commitments, perfectly aligning with their foundational principle that poverty eradication requires systemic economic justice beyond aid quotas.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on policy coherence, proposing strengthened integration of fair trade mechanisms to address root causes of poverty through equitable market access for African producers.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s alignment with their demand to combat corporate tax evasion as critical to achieving MDG 8, urging enhanced transparency in EU financial policies affecting developing nations.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the necessity of conditioning CAP and fisheries reforms on sustainability criteria to end EU practices undermining agricultural and marine resources in the Global South.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the call for gender-responsive development frameworks, emphasizing that maternal health targets cannot be met without explicit guarantees of reproductive rights and women’s autonomy.

SD strongly agrees the issue's emphasis on targeting aid to vulnerable groups, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to prioritizing women, children, and people with disabilities in development frameworks.  
SD approves the call for binding mechanisms to achieve the 0.7% GNI target, proposing enhanced accountability measures for underperforming states like Italy and Germany to ensure moral obligations are met.  
SD emphasizes the urgent need to address climate change as an enhancement opportunity, advocating for dedicated funding streams to help developing nations adapt without diverting existing MDG resources.  
SD endorses the report's balanced market mechanisms and legislative tools, urging accelerated implementation of financial transaction taxes to generate predictable development financing amid crisis-driven shortfalls.  
SD highlights the necessity to treat aid effectiveness as a core EU external policy priority, recommending stricter monitoring of fund allocation to prevent regression in hunger and poverty indicators post-crisis.

ECR rejects the issue's poverty eradication framework for neglecting property rights formalization as a catalyst for economic empowerment.  
This fully condemns with ECR's position that market-driven stakeholdership trumps aid dependency in development strategies.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as legal recognition of informal businesses, which ECR deems essential to unlock nine trillion dollars in dormant capital.  
ECR opposes the singular focus on aid quantity targets as inconsistent with their advocacy for systemic reforms enabling asset ownership in informal economies.  
The issue's maternal health and education priorities are deemed insufficient without parallel mechanisms to capitalize slum properties and micro-enterprises.

GUE_NGL strongly sanctions the issue's urgent call for EU member states to meet the 0.7% GNI development aid target by 2015, aligning perfectly with the party's longstanding commitment to eradicate extreme poverty and address the EUR 20 billion funding deficit highlighted in the report.  
GUE_NGL strongly sanctions integrating MDG achievement as a non-negotiable requirement in all EU external agreements, effectively advancing the principle that no treaties should be ratified unless they demonstrably prioritize poverty reduction and social development.  
GUE_NGL proposes redirecting funds within Economic Partnership Agreements from trade-related allocations to directly finance primary education and maternal health programs, ensuring these partnerships fully support rather than undermine Millennium Development Goals.  
GUE_NGL strongly sanctions maintaining the issue's stringent demands against postponement of MDG targets, particularly emphasizing accelerated action in sub-Saharan Africa where poverty rates have risen despite global crises.  
GUE_NGL approves the emphasis on policy coherence across EU development frameworks, urging strict accountability mechanisms to prevent diluted commitments under austerity pretexts.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need to uphold the commitments made under the 2000 Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), emphasizing the moral imperative to eradicate extreme poverty, achieve universal primary education, promote gender equality, reduce child and maternal mortality, combat HIV/AIDS and other diseases, ensure environmental sustainability, and foster global partnerships for development. It called for increased financial resources, policy coherence, and accountability mechanisms, urging EU member states to meet their target of allocating 0.7% of gross national income to official development assistance by 2015, while addressing inequalities, enhancing aid effectiveness, and integrating the MDGs into broader EU external action and development cooperation frameworks.

title: Cohesion Policy and Research and Innovation Strategies for smart specialisation (RIS3): REPORT on Cohesion Policy and Research and Innovation Strategies for Smart Specialisation (RIS3)
background: The EU’s cohesion policy frameworks, aligned with Europe 2020 goals, mandated member states to develop 2014-2020 Research and Innovation Strategies for Smart Specialisation (RIS3) to optimize regional competitiveness through targeted investments, requiring alignment with structural funds and addressing disparities in innovation capacity. The Parliament will discuss RIS3 implementation within cohesion policy to enhance innovation-driven regional development.

stances.stance:
EPP completely approves the issue's emphasis on territorial cooperation as the quintessence of EU values, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to fostering cross-border trust, institutional partnerships, and transboundary infrastructure to address peripheral disparities.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the prioritization of SMEs and start-ups, recognizing their role as the backbone of innovation and job creation, and applauds the call to double Horizon 2020 support for regional entrepreneurial ecosystems in line with EPP's 2023 economic resilience agenda.  
EPP completely approves the Alpine macro-regional strategy's balanced approach to sustainable tourism, transport connectivity, and economic vitality, which advances EPP's priority of harmonizing environmental stewardship with generational livelihood security in geographically sensitive areas.  
EPP unequivocally supports maintaining cohesion policy post-2020 funding levels and synergies between ESI Funds, Horizon 2020, and EFSI, reflecting EPP's manifesto pledge to eliminate innovation gaps through granular, asset-based regional development.  
EPP proposes strengthening multi-stakeholder governance frameworks to enhance administrative capacities and quadruple-helix collaboration, ensuring RIS3 strategies avoid bureaucratic fragmentation while preserving focus on sectoral innovation and SME competitiveness.

EFDD rejects the cohesion policy’s reliance on centralized funding redistribution, entirely condemning with EFDD’s position that market-driven competition—not taxpayer-funded subsidies—should drive SME growth.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as deregulation, opposing EFDD’s demand to eliminate bureaucratic burdens on SMEs instead of redistributing EU funds.  
EFDD opposes RIS3’s top-down governance as inconsistent with EFDD’s principles, arguing it perpetuates cronyism rather than fostering genuine competition.  
The issue fails to address EFDD’s call to abolish cohesion policy entirely, prioritizing market freedom over state-managed innovation strategies.  
EFDD condemns the misuse of ESI Funds for interregional cooperation, viewing it as wasteful centralization incompatible with subsidiarity and fiscal responsibility.

ENF rejects the allocation of ESI Funds to regions with systemic corruption, citing Moldova as evidence that current safeguards fail to protect taxpayer interests.  
ENF opposes EU macro-regional strategies like the Alpine Convention integration, arguing they undermine national sovereignty and local governance frameworks protected by the 1991 treaty.  
ENF partially approves RIS3's regional empowerment goals but demands constitutional guarantees against centralizing reforms like Italy's, which contradict subsidiarity principles.  
ENF criticizes the issue's biodiversity approach as neglecting alpine cultural landscapes, insisting agricultural producers—not EU directives—should lead ecosystem management.  
ENF fundamentally disputes innovation funding mechanisms that prioritize bureaucratic compliance over SME needs for tax stability, reduced regulations, and anti-dumping protections.

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the issue's emphasis on multi-stakeholder governance and SME prioritization, which aligns with their commitment to decentralized, participatory decision-making.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing infrastructure investment criteria to prioritize upgrades of underutilized existing assets over new megaprojects, citing cost-efficiency and sustainability benefits demonstrated in Alpine transport cases.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on regional granularity and energy transition alignment as effectively advancing their vision of place-based ecological modernization embedded in local productive ecosystems.  
GREEN_EFA urges stricter interregional cooperation requirements to prevent innovation disparities, advocating binding thresholds for knowledge-sharing between advanced and lagging regions in ESI Fund allocations.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the need to maintain grant-based support mechanisms in RIS3 implementation to avoid marginalizing social innovation initiatives that prioritize community impact over financial returns.

ALDE strongly accepts the issue’s prioritization of SMEs as central to EU growth, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to fostering entrepreneurship and simplifying Structural Fund procedures to bridge operational gaps between regional administrations and business needs.  
ALDE approves the emphasis on region-specific innovation strategies rooted in local assets, strongly advocating against replication of external models and urging granular, entrepreneurial discovery processes to maximize competitiveness.  
ALDE highlights the need to enhance financial support for regional partners implementing RIS3, proposing stricter allocation oversight to ensure ESI Funds directly empower local stakeholders in cross-sectoral innovation.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s alignment with multi-stakeholder governance and quadruple-helix collaboration, noting the Basque Country’s success as a model for integrating regional strengths into EU-wide competitiveness.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical role of interregional cooperation and synergies between ESI Funds and Horizon 2020, urging accelerated scaling of pilot projects like Eastern Macedonia and Thrace to reduce innovation disparities.

SD strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on SME prioritization and cross-sectoral innovation, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to equitable regional development through entrepreneurial empowerment.  
SD approves the call for enhanced ESI Fund-Horizon 2020 synergies, proposing simplified joint application procedures to reduce administrative burdens for SMEs as a technical refinement.  
SD highlights the need to operationalize the issue's governance principles by expanding the S3 platform’s mentorship programs for lagging regions, particularly in rural digital infrastructure.  
SD emphasizes that the quadruple-helix collaboration model effectively advances SD’s vision of participatory policymaking, though suggests explicit inclusion of youth entrepreneurship networks in RIS3 monitoring frameworks.  
SD welcomes the focus on low-tech/social innovation as critical to territorial cohesion, urging accelerated ITI implementation to address payment delays criticized by SME stakeholders.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of Research and Innovation Strategies for Smart Specialisation (RIS3) as central tools for achieving Europe 2020 goals, emphasizing their role in fostering economic, social, and territorial cohesion through knowledge-based growth, job creation, and innovation. It highlighted the need for RIS3 to be rooted in regional strengths, entrepreneurial discovery processes, and multi-stakeholder governance to avoid generic priorities and ensure alignment with local assets, while addressing innovation gaps between and within regions. The resolution stressed the underutilized potential of interregional cooperation, noting that 15% of EU Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) could be allocated for such collaboration, and called for enhanced synergies between ESI Funds, Horizon 2020, and the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) to maximize impact. It urged regions to prioritize support for SMEs, start-ups, and cross-sectoral innovation, including social and low-tech innovation, while improving monitoring mechanisms and data collection to track progress. The Parliament criticized insufficient administrative capacities and top-down approaches in some Member States, advocating for stronger regional involvement and adherence to partnership principles. It welcomed pilot projects like the one in Eastern Macedonia and Thrace, scaled to eight Member States until 2017, and called for a 2017 review of RIS3 to refine strategies, boost granularity, and align future cohesion policies. The resolution also emphasized the role of smart cities, energy transitions, and quadruple-helix collaboration (public, private, academic, civil society) in driving innovation, while urging the Commission to strengthen the S3 platform’s support for lagging regions and disseminate lessons learned to improve post-2020 strategies.

title: EU Trust Fund for Africa: the implications for development and humanitarian aid: REPORT on the EU Trust Fund for Africa: the implications for development and humanitarian aid
background: The EU established the Trust Fund for Africa in 2015 to address migration root causes in fragile regions, pooling EU and member state resources alongside existing development instruments. The Parliament will discuss the fund’s alignment with development goals and humanitarian principles, focusing on resource allocation and institutional coordination.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely supports the issue's emphasis on linking EUTF implementation to long-term development objectives, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to sustainable governance and poverty reduction in partner countries.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the demand for increased member state contributions to the EUTF, reinforcing EPP's principle of shared responsibility in addressing migration root causes through robust ODA-compliant investments.  
EPP entirely supports the call to integrate crisis response mechanisms into the MFF while preserving budget unity, mirroring EPP's 2023 agenda for flexible yet accountable EU financial architectures.  
EPP proposes strengthening parliamentary oversight provisions to enhance transparency in fund allocation, ensuring democratic scrutiny aligns with EPP's governance priorities without opposing the issue's core framework.  
EPP entirely supports the issue’s conflict-sensitive approach, which directly advances EPP’s human rights agenda by conditioning aid on beneficiary governments’ adherence to rule-of-law principles.

GREEN_EFA absolutely approves the issue’s unequivocal rejection of diverting development funds toward migration control, which perfectly aligns with their mandate to prioritize poverty reduction, education, and gender equality over securitized agendas.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the demand for strict adherence to ODA criteria, as this safeguards development assistance from being weaponized against displaced populations—a core tenet of their human rights framework.  
GREEN_EFA celebrates the emphasis on conflict-sensitive approaches and civil society inclusion, recognizing these as essential to addressing root causes of instability in line with their advocacy for participatory, locally led solutions.  
GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the issue’s condemnation of cooperation with human rights-violating governments, mirroring their uncompromising stance on ethical governance and accountability in EU external action.  
GREEN_EFA affirms the call to integrate SDGs into all EUTF projects, particularly health and youth empowerment, which aligns perfectly with their 2030 Agenda implementation strategy for equitable, sustainable development.

ALDE entirely endorses the issue's insistence on maintaining ODA criteria to prioritize poverty reduction and gender equality, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to rights-based development frameworks.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the demand for civil society inclusion in EUTF project cycles, recognizing this as essential to uphold democratic accountability in EU external action.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the EU Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF), established in 2015 with a €1.8 billion EU contribution to address root causes of migration and instability in 23 African countries, emphasizing development, resilience, and migration management. The resolution stressed that EUTF funds must adhere to Official Development Assistance (ODA) criteria, focusing on poverty reduction, human rights, gender equality, and conflict-sensitive approaches, while condemning misuse for migration control. It called for transparency, accountability, and civil society involvement in project design, implementation, and evaluation, and highlighted risks of diverting aid from least developed countries (LDCs). Parliament urged revising the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) to integrate crisis mechanisms, restore budget unity, and ensure democratic oversight, demanding regular reporting and alignment with Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly on peace, education, health, and gender equality. Concerns included coherence with EU external policies, migration cooperation under the Valletta Summit, and safeguarding humanitarian principles, while opposing cooperation with governments violating human rights. The resolution emphasized the need for holistic solutions balancing security, development, and migration challenges, ensuring funds prioritize local needs, youth empowerment, and sustainable growth.

resolution: The European Parliament raised deep concerns over the global trend of shrinking civil society space, marked by restrictive laws, stigmatization, harassment, and violence against civil society organizations (CSOs) and human rights defenders (HRDs), particularly in developing countries and conflict zones. It emphasized the vital role of independent, diverse civil society in promoting democracy, human rights, sustainable development, and accountability, aligning with the 2030 Agenda and SDGs 16 and 17. The resolution called for enhanced EU support through increased funding, including the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights (EIDHR) and the 2014-2020 DCI Multiannual Indicative Programme, to strengthen CSOs’ capacity, ensure safe environments, and address gender-based repression. It urged the EU to lead by example, uphold fundamental freedoms internally, and integrate human rights into trade agreements, development policies, and security strategies, while opposing counter-terrorism measures that unduly restrict civic space. The Parliament advocated for a coordinated EU response, including a "Shrinking Space Monitoring and Early Warning" mechanism, annual lists of high-risk countries, and systematic engagement with multilateral bodies to hold governments accountable. It highlighted the need to protect marginalized groups, women, youth, and HRDs, and demanded binding corporate human rights due diligence. Additionally, the resolution stressed the importance of EU Delegations in supporting local CSOs, simplifying funding access, and promoting tripartite dialogues between governments, civil society, and the EU to address root causes of repression and ensure policy coherence.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about enhancing Policy Coherence for Development (PCD) to achieve the 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda, emphasizing its critical role in addressing poverty, inequality, and global challenges. It highlighted the EU’s responsibility to integrate PCD across all policies, particularly in migration, where development objectives must address root causes of displacement, ensure safe migration routes, and avoid diverting development aid (ODA) for migration control. The resolution stressed trade and finance reforms, noting the EU provided €11.7 billion in Aid for Trade (2013), urging alignment of trade agreements with SDGs, combating tax evasion, illicit financial flows, and promoting corporate accountability through binding frameworks like the Bangladesh Sustainability Compact. It called for innovative financing (e.g., financial transaction tax) and reaffirmed the 0.7% GNP ODA target. Climate action demands included implementing the Paris Agreement, limiting warming to below 2°C, and boosting climate finance for developing countries. Gender equality was prioritized via the EU Gender Action Plan 2016-2020, while security policies were linked to development through crisis prevention and governance reforms. The resolution advocated stronger institutional coordination, impact assessments, ex-post evaluations, and an independent complaint mechanism for communities affected by EU policies. It urged systemic integration of SDGs into EU decision-making, emphasizing domestic resource mobilization, fair tax systems, and support for developing countries’ capacity-building in health, agriculture, and sustainable infrastructure.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of SMEs, which constitute 99% of EU businesses and provide over 100 million jobs, in driving economic growth, innovation, and social cohesion. It emphasized the need to enhance support through Cohesion Policy, noting that €70 billion allocated to SMEs in 2007-2013 created 263,000 jobs, with funding doubling to €140 billion for 2014-2020. The resolution highlighted challenges such as administrative burdens, delayed payments, and limited access to finance, particularly for microenterprises and start-ups, and called for simplified procedures, reduced bureaucracy, and improved use of financial instruments like the SME Initiative. It urged leveraging ESI Funds to promote green growth, circular economy practices, and digitalization, while ensuring compliance with the Late Payment Directive to stabilize SME cash flows. The Parliament stressed the importance of smart specialization strategies, gender-inclusive entrepreneurship, and internationalization, noting only 13% of SMEs operate globally. It advocated for better coordination between EU funds (e.g., Horizon 2020, COSME) and regional strategies, increased post-2020 funding, and streamlined public procurement to support SMEs. Additionally, it called for monitoring implementation delays, enhancing transparency, and addressing disparities in underdeveloped regions, while emphasizing compliance with COP21 goals and integrating refugees through SME initiatives.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the imperative of integrating digital technologies into EU development policy to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), emphasizing their role in education, gender equality, infrastructure, and inclusive growth. It highlighted the Digital4Development (D4D) strategy’s alignment with the 2030 Agenda, stressing the need to address digital divides, including disparities in internet access—noting that 1.1 billion people lack official identity documentation (78% in sub-Saharan Africa and Asia) and over half the global population remains offline, jeopardizing SDG 9’s target of universal internet access in least developed countries (LDCs) by 2020. The resolution called for increased funding under the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) to bolster digital infrastructure, e-governance, and cybersecurity in developing countries, while addressing environmental risks like electronic waste (e-waste) and the 2-5% global CO2 emissions from digital technologies. It urged policy coherence to ensure digital trade aligns with sustainable development, including consumer protection, data privacy, and competition policies to counter monopolies by major tech firms. The Parliament emphasized digital literacy and skills training, integration of ICTs into education systems, and support for micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs), particularly women-led businesses, to enhance economic inclusion. It advocated for ethical humanitarian innovation, risk assessments in digital projects, and partnerships with regional bodies like the African Union to advance connectivity and regulatory frameworks. Environmental sustainability measures included promoting circular economy practices, reducing reliance on conflict minerals like coltan, and supporting agro-ecological farming through digital tools. The resolution also underscored digital technology’s potential in health services, disaster response, birth registration, and combating corruption via e-governance, while cautioning against risks to privacy, labor markets, and democratic processes.
